webFeature.description_html: The prefers-reduced-motion CSS media query sets styles based on whether the user prefers to minimize the amount of non-essential animations on the device, such as scrolling, panning, zooming, and strobing.
webFeature.name: prefers-reduced-motion media query

example.codeHighlighted: @media (prefers-color-scheme: dark) { .foo { background: #333; color: white; } }

webFeature.description_html: The prefers-color-scheme CSS media query sets styles based on the requested color scheme, light or dark.
webFeature.name: prefers-color-scheme media query

example.codeHighlighted: @media (prefers-contrast: more) { .contrast { outline: 2px solid black; } }

webFeature.description_html: The prefers-contrast CSS media query sets styles based on whether the user prefers more or less contrast, the difference between foreground and background colors.
webFeature.name: prefers-contrast media query

entity.name: Not applicable
entity.description: No use cases, no pain, no issues.
entity.descriptionClean: No use cases, no pain, no issues.

example.codeHighlighted: @media (forced-colors: active) { .button { border: 2px green solid; } }

webFeature.description_html: The forced-colors CSS @media rule detects when a user has chosen to use a forced colors mode, also known as high-contrast mode, and the forced-color-adjust CSS property sets whether forced colors apply to an element.
webFeature.name: Forced colors

entity.name: Storybook

webFeature.description_html: The color-scheme CSS property sets which color schemes (light or dark) an element uses and may prevent automatic dark mode adjustments by the browser.
webFeature.name: color-scheme

webFeature.description_html: The prefers-reduced-data CSS media query detects whether the user has a preference for using less network traffic. For example, you can use this media query to avoid loading large font files and use a system font instead.
webFeature.name: prefers-reduced-data media query

webFeature.description_html: The :focus-visible CSS pseudo-class selects elements that match the :focus pseudo-class and meets the browser's criteria for visually emphasizing focused elements.
webFeature.name: :focus-visible
